content: The Act titled "Making Every Representative's Integrity Transparent Act of 2014" or "MERIT Act" prohibits campaign committees from employing relatives of candidates. The MERIT Act prohibits campaign committees from employing relatives of candidates in paid positions. This includes both authorized committees of candidates and leadership PACs. The MERIT Act prohibits campaign committees from employing relatives of candidates in paid positions, including those in leadership PACs. The term "relative" is defined broadly to include various family members. The effective date of this amendment is 90 days after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 3. LIMIT ON INTEREST RATE PAID BY CAMPAIGN COMMITTEES ON LOANS MADE BY CANDIDATES. Limit on Interest Rate Paid on Loans Made by Candidates: An authorized committee of a candidate accepting a loan from the candidate cannot pay interest on the loan at an annual rate higher than the prime rate as of the date the loan is agreed to plus 2 percentage points. The prime rate is defined as the bank prime loan rate published in the Federal Reserve Statistical Release. The amendment made by subsection (a) applies to loans made on or after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 4. ENHANCED DISCLOSURE OF CERTAIN INFORMATION BY CAMPAIGN COMMITTEES. Loans made by candidates under the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 are amended to include detailed terms and conditions of the loan, such as the aggregate amount, interest rate, repayment schedule, fees, penalties, and requirements for loan forgiveness or deferment. Loans made by candidates under the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 are amended to include detailed terms and conditions of the loan, such as the aggregate amount, interest rate, repayment schedule, fees, penalties, and requirements for loan forgiveness or deferment. Payments to relatives of candidates are also subject to disclosure requirements under the Act. The amendments made by this section require disclosure of relatives serving as officers or directors in business organizations related to candidates. These changes apply to reports filed under the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 5. CLARIFICATION OF RULES APPLICABLE TO USES OF CONTRIBUTIONS ACCEPTED BY POLITICAL COMMITTEES. The text chunk discusses amendments to the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 regarding the use of contributions by political committees. It prohibits the conversion of funds for personal use and clarifies that contributions can be used for authorized expenditures in connection with political activities and other lawful purposes. The amendments to the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 allow contributions to be used by political committees for political activities and other lawful purposes, prohibiting the conversion of funds for personal use. The amendments made to the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 specify the use of contributions for political activities and other lawful purposes, preventing funds from being used for personal use. The effective date for these changes is after December 2014. SEC. 6. REQUIRING LOBBYISTS TO IDENTIFY RELATIVES WHO ARE COVERED OFFICIALS AND DISCLOSE LOBBYING CONTACTS WITH RELATIVES. Section 4(b)(6) of the Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995 is amended to require registrants to disclose the name, position, and any relatives who are covered officials for employees acting as lobbyists on behalf of clients. The Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995 requires registrants to disclose covered officials and their relatives who are employees acting as lobbyists for clients. Updates to registration are also required for employees who become relatives of covered officials after registration. The Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995 mandates registrants to disclose employees who become relatives of covered officials and update their registration within 90 days. The amendments apply to registrations made after the enactment of the Act. The Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995 requires registrants to include information on lobbying contacts with relatives in their quarterly reports. Amendments to the Act mandate disclosure of any lobbyists acting on behalf of a client. The Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995 now requires registrants to disclose if any lobbyist contacted a relative who is a covered legislative or executive branch official on behalf of a client. The amendment applies to reports filed for quarterly periods starting after the enactment date. The Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995 now requires registrants to disclose if a lobbyist contacted a relative who is a covered legislative or executive branch official on behalf of a client. The amendment defines "relative" to include various family members and in-laws.
